newsitem.title: RUSSIA: SOCCER-RUSSIA MAY OPT FOR AUTUMN-SPRING SEASON.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-RUSSIA MAY OPT FOR AUTUMN-SPRING SEASON.

text.p: Russia's top soccer official wants to defy the elements and change the country's domestic soccer calendar, bringing it into line with most European countries.

Vyacheslav Koloskov, president of the Russian Football Union, said he supported an autumn-spring season for the 18 premier league teams to improve the country's disappointing record in European competitions.
The current season runs from early April to early November, sparing supporters and players the ordeal of freezing winter temperatures.
During the dark winter months many pitches are carpeted with ice or are ankle-deep in mud. Only a few stadiums have underground heating systems.
Koloskov said at least half of the premier division coaches and players supported the transition to autumn-spring but it was not clear when the plan could be implemented.
"I put forward this idea in September and will try to bring it into effect," he said, adding that he hoped it could be introduced next year.
"The Russian and west European calenders don't coincide at all. When our teams are playing their west European counterparts are resting and vice versa."
Koloskov said some coaches opposed his idea but most were from teams languishing in the lower reaches of the table with little prospect of playing in European tournaments.
He said the he issue would be settled at a meeting of the Russian Football Union on January 22.
Russia has no covered soccer stadiums, although late last year Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov launched a plan to build a roof over the 100,000-seat Luzhniki stadium, home to Moscow Torpedo.
Work has started and is due to be completed late next year.
"Then we could play football in the domestic championship and European cups throughout the year," Luzhkov said.
